headline.main: Data Offer A Head Count In Health Care

docs.abstract: Small nonprofit group Center for Medical Consumers has compiled numbers from data collected on every hospital patient by New York State Health Department in order to provide consumers with information on how often a particular doctor or hospital in New York State performs certain type of surgery (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time, consumers can learn how often a particular doctor or hospital in New York performs a certain type of surgery, in what consumer advocates call an important step toward arming patients with the information they need to shop for health care. A small nonprofit group, the Center for Medical Consumers, compiled the numbers from data collected on every hospital patient by the State Health Department. It chose 21 common surgical procedures, like mastectomy and knee replacement, and determined how many of each were performed at each hospital, and by each doctor, across the state in 1998. The center will release the numbers at a news conference here Monday, but it began posting the information on its Web site on Friday (www.medicalconsumers.org).
